article.title: Casimir Meets Poisson: Improved Quark/Gluon Discrimination with Counting Observables

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the dashed line in the figure represent?
choices: A branch that satisfies the soft drop condition.
A branch that fails the soft drop condition.
The trunk of the clustering tree.
The angular cutoff scale.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of distribution does the soft drop multiplicity nSD approximately follow?
choices: Gaussian
Exponential
Poisson
Uniform

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the shaded area A(f) in the (log 1/θ, log 1/z) plane represent?
choices: Region of allowed emissions
Region of forbidden emissions
Phase space area of the groomed jet
Phase space area of the original jet

multiple_choice_question.text: Which observable shows the best quark/gluon discrimination power in the figure?
choices: Groomed Jet Mass
Jet Mass
Track Multiplicity
Groomed Jet Radius

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the shaded area Aemit in the (log 1/θ, log 1/z) plane represent for soft drop multiplicity?
choices: Region of forbidden emissions
Region of soft-dropped emissions
Region of allowed emissions
Region of collinear emissions

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the figure demonstrate about the soft drop multiplicity?
choices: It confirms the presence of flavor-changing effects.
It validates the prediction of Sudakov behavior.
It verifies the prediction of Casimir scaling and Poisson behavior at LL.
It shows the importance of non-perturbative corrections.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the figure illustrate regarding Poisson-distributed observables?
choices: They exhibit Casimir scaling similar to additive observables.
Their discrimination power is independent of the mean value.
Their discrimination power improves as the mean value increases.
They are less effective than additive observables for quark/gluon discrimination.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of restricting the minimum relative kt in the figure?
choices: To isolate collinear emissions.
To exclude non-perturbative emissions.
To identify the hardest emission.
To simplify the calculation at LL order.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from the figure regarding the optimal value of β for soft drop multiplicity?
choices: β = 0 yields the best discrimination power.
β > −1 is preferred to maximize perturbative phase space.
β = −1 gives the optimal perturbative discrimination power.
The optimal β value is independent of the jet pT.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the impact of decreasing  ΛNP on the discrimination power of soft drop multiplicity, as shown in the figure?
choices: Decreasing  ΛNP consistently improves discrimination power.
There is no gain in performance when  ΛNP is taken below a certain value.
Decreasing  ΛNP  increases the impact of non-perturbative effects.
ΛNP has no significant impact on the discrimination power.

multiple_choice_question.text: What effect do NLL corrections have on the soft drop multiplicity distributions and ROC curves compared to the LL calculation?
choices: They significantly enhance the discrimination power.
They shift the peak of the distribution to higher nSD values.
They introduce oscillations in the distributions.
They result in a slight decrease in discrimination power.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the figure demonstrate about non-perturbative effects on the nSD distribution in Vincia?
choices: Non-perturbative effects are dominant even for large zcut values.
Non-perturbative effects are negligible for the chosen parameter values.
Non-perturbative effects significantly enhance the discrimination power.
Non-perturbative effects introduce a non-Poissonian shape to the distribution.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the relative performance of soft drop multiplicity (nSD) compared to jet mass for quark/gluon discrimination, as shown in the figure?
choices: nSD consistently outperforms jet mass.
Jet mass yields better discrimination power than nSD.
Both nSD and jet mass achieve comparable performance.
The performance depends significantly on the parton shower generator used.

multiple_choice_question.text: How well do the NLL predictions for the nSD distributions and ROC curves agree with the results from the parton shower generators?
choices: There is perfect agreement between the NLL calculation and all generators.
The agreement is generally good, with some variations between generators.
The NLL calculation significantly underestimates the discrimination power.
The generators fail to reproduce the key features of the nSD distribution.

multiple_choice_question.text: What happens to the discrimination power of the collinear-unsafe soft drop multiplicity as zcut is decreased?
choices: It decreases significantly.
It improves until reaching a plateau.
It exhibits oscillatory behavior.
It becomes independent of zcut.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the figure illustrate regarding the RG evolution of the collinear-unsafe soft drop multiplicity?
choices: The evolved distributions lose all discriminatory power.
The evolution shifts the distributions to lower nSD values.
The RG evolution exhibits good agreement with the Vincia results at high scale.
The shape of the distributions remains unchanged during the evolution.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key prediction of the GFF approach regarding the RG evolution of the quark/gluon ROC curves for the collinear-unsafe soft drop multiplicity?
choices: The ROC curves exhibit significant changes with energy scale.
The ROC curves remain mostly unchanged with energy scale.
The discrimination power increases rapidly with energy scale.
The GFF approach fails to provide reliable predictions for the ROC curves.

multiple_choice_question.text: What happens to the difference in means (G(1)-Q(1)) and the difference in variances (σ²G - σ²Q) for the soft drop multiplicity at high energies?
choices: Both differences approach zero.
Both differences grow proportionally to the energy scale.
Both differences approach constant values.
The difference in means approaches a constant, while the difference in variances diverges.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the quark/gluon discrimination power of weighted soft drop multiplicity change as the weight parameter κ increases?
choices: It improves significantly.
It remains unchanged.
It decreases monotonically.
It exhibits oscillatory behavior.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the characteristic feature of the weighted soft drop multiplicity distributions (n(κ)SD) in the perturbative regime, as shown in the figure?
choices: Smooth Gaussian shape
Sharp edges and discontinuities
Exponential decay
Oscillatory behavior

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the RG evolution of the collinear-unsafe weighted soft drop multiplicity (with κ = 1) compare to the unweighted (κ = 0) case in terms of discrimination power?
choices: The weighted case yields significantly better separation power.
Both cases achieve comparable separation power.
The unweighted case is more effective for quark/gluon discrimination.
The weighted case loses all discriminatory power during the evolution.
